Low Carb Diets and Gout??

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎10-24-2011 11:47 PM

So, just before all the stuff with my cousins and aunt and uncle happened, we got a phone call from my brother in Hawai'i! Besides normal family talk, he told us he has lost 30 lbs. Being over 40, having a sister and a mom with type 1 and type 2 diabetes (respectively), and having had weight problems for quite a while, he knows he needs to get his weight down and keep it down. Last time he lost weight, he used the Atkins diet with outstanding results: He was as trim as he was when he was active duty in the military. He tried it again, but this time, he has not had as much success and a problem has cropped up. This time, during his "induction" phase, as he was eating pounds of meat as his meals, he noticed he was developing some pain in his feet. It got worse as time went on, until he found he could barely stand. His doctor has diagnosed him with gout in his foot and told him that it is likely the gout was caused by the diet, since the diet was the only thing that has changed.

 

Have any of you who have used the ultra-low carb diets developed gout? If you have, what did you do to manage the condition? Did you modify the diet, use drugs, or what? He's also become scared to run, as he still has pain and is afraid to aggravate the condition. Did you have to change your exercise regimen?

 

Any insights are appreciated!

 

Angela

‎10-25-2011 01:26 AM

Angela,

 

Developing gout from a low carb diet is not something that anyone has mentioned here, even though some people who have gout have posted.

 

Gout has a different set of foods that aggravate it, and your bother would do well to look up the diet for gout on the web if his doctor ahs not provided that information. It is different than the diet for diabetes, and people with both have a problem balancing the dietary needs of 2 different conditions. Waht is left for them to eat?  Kind of like people with celiac disease and diabetes do, or people who choose to be vegan and then have diabetes.

 

Fortunately though, unless you just didn't mention it, your brother doesn't have diabetes, so he should be able to adopt a diet adapted for gout, and should be able to reduce intake enough tot also lose weight.

Morris

Diagnosed Type 2, with an A1c of 11.4 in 2003; averaging a 5.0 A1c since then with diet, exercise and Glipizide XL + meds for blood pressure and cholesterol.  A bit dated, but scroll down on this page if you want to know more ...

Angela, my non-diabetic FIL has had gout flare ups a couple of times. We bought him pure cherry juice for the first time, then the second time he went to the Doc because of the pain( he couldn't even stand the sheets on his feet), they gave him a prescription .  Can't remember what it was but I think Rae takes it, I'll ask her to join in.

We bought black cherry pills for Hubby when we thought he had gout but it turned out to be arthritis in his first joint above his big toe......but still very painful.

 

Good luck to your Brother...........................Big Red.........................Peace

‎10-25-2011 02:16 AM

Purely anecdotal.

 

I have no gout, nor do any of the low-carbers I presently communicate with. The only person I know personally with gout is my brother-in-law and he definitely does not eat low-carb; rather the reverse.

Cheers, Alan, Type 2, d&e metformin 2000mg, Australia.

‎10-25-2011 02:37 AM

Angela, I have had no experience with gout but my first thought was that the Atkins diet would not be the best for gout.

 

I googled "foods that cause gout" and got many results similar to this one....

 

http://www.health.com/health/gallery/0,,20448674,00.html

 

Certainly the large quantities of protein and fat laden foods are likely to build up uric acid and Atkins did advise dieters to eat all the meats and heavy fats that they wanted.

 

Perhaps everything in moderation might be the best route to take once your brother is over this flare up.

 

Dianne

Dianne

Diagnosed as type 2 in 2005 with an A1c of 9.1

Started with metformin and a low dose of an ARB for blood pressure. Added a sulfonylurea (a med that helps my pancreas produce my own insulin) Also a low dose of Crestor to lower my cholesterol.
After 7 years I could no longer tolerate metformin so am doing my best to keep control with a max dose of the sulfonylurea and lots of walking, some swimming.

Re: Low Carb Diets and Gout??

‎10-25-2011 02:45 AM

I have a son with gout, so this was a good review for me. 

 

This page from the Mayo Clinic discusses the diet for gout:  http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/gout-diet/MY01137

 

It's not so much the absence of carbs that would cause a problem, as an excess of meat. Meat, as it is digested, is a source of uric acid, and it is the formation of uric acid crystals in the joints that causes pain and damage. A high protein diet is definitely not a good strategy for weight loss with diabetes.

 

 

"Molly" (aka mollythed)
Type 2 diabetes diagnosed in 1995, now managed with Lantus, Novolog and Metformin; diet and exercise.
My late husband had diabetes. My three adult sons also have type 2 diabetes.

Hi there Angela,

 

I am a diabetic AND I have gout too (lucky me uh? LOL). Gout runs like wildfire in my family, together with diabetes...

 

Gout is not exactly alike for everyone. Some people are more sensitive to certain things than others. For example, I am very sensitive to tomatoes: if I eat a medium sized tomato a day for 3-4 days, I know I will have a flare up (mine hits me in the right hand. At the base of the thumb. My last flare up was about 3 weeks ago. I had been flare up free for a couple of years...), however of medium intensity. I am less sensitive to most other things that are notable culprits for flare ups, like red meat.

 

As far as I am concerned, to control gout I just need to not over indulge in foods that can cause flare ups. Having a varied diet should be enough for most, it is for sure for me.

My suggestion to your cousin is to vary his diet as much as possible, alternating "safe" food with food that is not that good for the disease. For example, eat red meat every 3-4 days or so, instead of every day. When not eating that, eat chicken/turkey or some other form protein not obtained via red meat.

Note though that if he's THAT bad at the moment, I'd suggest for him to just cut out red meat for 2-3 weeks and then reintroduce it gradually. That's what I would do if I was in his shoes. What I wrote is thru personal experience, I am no doctor, but I can tell you that the first time that gout showed up in me, parachute pants were the rage. So it's quite a while ago and I have managed it very well since...

 

PS: ok here's a little further insight...Years ago I put on my fridge a magnetic board on which I wrote the food that I need to be cautious (=not to be eaten in large quantities) re. gout and here are the foods that in MY case are more susceptible to cause my gout to flare up: tomatoes (these, as I said, are killers for me, more than anything else), alcohol beverages, red meat, butter, fruit in general, jams+marmalades, peas+beans, crustaceans.

Name: Al
Location: Massachusetts South Shore
Diabetes Type: 2
A1C results: 17 (at dx), 8.3 (2 months after dx), 5.2, 5.2, 5.1, 5.2 (<-- latest 10.10.2012)

*** Boston Bruins - 2011 Stanley Cup Champions ***

‎10-25-2011 07:27 AM

I have gout and diabetes 2. Both are in the hereditary category. I have used the black cherry capsules to help with the pain. There are several meds available however my doc will not give them to me as they can cause wear and tear on the kidneys along with the diabetes.

 

He does need to be tested to determine if it is gout. Uric acid build up in the body is the culprit and a level above 6 will determine if it is indeed gout or arthritis. The uric acid is a natural antioxidant in the body but the level can be increased by certain foods, organ meats being the highest instigator. I doubt very seriously if the low carb diet is the cause of his flare ups. At lot has to do with age. Being 40 and over, changes in the body will most likely start to take place.

_________________________________________________

My FIL has gout flare ups from time to time and is pre-diabetic.  For him it is red meat that causes the flares.  It seems that most people just have to find out what foods cause their flare-ups and avoid those foods
